text:
Pierrepont Street, north side, near Fulton Street. No. 159 is the frame House with the hip-roof. It was a Cafe known for fifty years as the "Hole in the Wall", and was kept by Dominick Colgan and George Werner, and at a later date by John H. Ham. Also known as "The Assembly" in 1904.

About 1918.?

Eugene L. Armbruster collection.

153-161 Pierrepont Street, north side, west of Fulton Street. The frame home in the center, No. 159, was still standing in (1929).

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1) Fulton Street, north from, but not including Pierrepont Street. In the extreme background, from left to right is shown the towers of the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a view further west.

153 Pierrepont Street, north side, eastward to Fulton Street.

November 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Pierrepont Street, east from Henry towards Fulton Streets.

August 10, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Fulton Street, west side, between Pierrepont (left), and Clinton Streets (right), showing the Fulton Street (B.M.T) Elevated Line. At the left, is the Brooklyn Savings Bank Building, which extends to the N.E. corner of Pierrepont and Clinton Streets. In the background from left to right, are the Crescent Apartments and the Hotel Touraine.

April 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
